interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

lg.l: Ailean Duinn o i shiulainshiubhlainn leat
Hir ir ri e ho hi o hug oirean o
Ailean Duinn ho hi shiubhlainshiubhlainn leat
S fliuch an t sidside us buan a ghailion
Dh fuadDh' fhuadaicheadh i na fir on charraig
Ailean Duinn o i shiulain leat
Dh fuadDh' fhuadaicheadh i na fir on fhearain
ChuirChuireadh i dh-Eirinn iad no Mhannain
S chuirchuireadh i ad a bhoid a dh-aineoindh-aindeoin
S cha be sin mo rogh cala
Ach Caolas Stiadair anns na h-Earradh
No Loch-Miabhaig anns na Beannaibh
Far am bi na fir gan tarruinn
S far am bi na h eoin eir chrannaibh
Sa chuag sa Cheit / Cheitean ?
Gire mise their mo leireadh
S cha ne bas a chruith sa Cheitean?
Sann an diudiugh is beag mo speis dhedheth
Sud bhiodh agam buaile spreispreidh
Seach a flichead sa tha do leine
Ach uthu bhi sa chuan gun sgeul ort
MucaMucan marmara eir thu do reubaireubaidh
Gur smise their mo sparradh
Cha b e bas a chuir sa ghailghaillion
Ach uthu bhi sa chauan a falfalach
Gun chiste chaoil gun strol gun anart
Far nach eireirich grian no gealgealach
Ach na cheil Dia eir h-anam
Na fhuair mi ghad chuid gun cheanncheannach
Fhuair mi slat no dha dhan anart
Neapaiguin dha'n sioda bhallach
Thug uthu fhein a ghraighraidh a Mannain
Sid a RiRigh s nach mi bha mar riut
Gad bann anns tiura feamad
Na ga b-anns a chladh a falfalach
Sid a RiRigh snach mi bha lamh riut
Ga be sgeir no bogh an traitraigh uthu
DholDholainn deoch ga b olc le cach e
S cha b ann a fhion dearg na Spainne
Ach dhan fhuil tha n lag do bhragaidbhraghaid.

div.p:
CompComposed by Ann Campbell nieannighean
DhonilDhomhnuill ic Iain Oig to Alan mac Mhic
MhurchadhMhurachaidh. Alan was coming from Stornoway
His brobrother saildsailed in a vessel to call at Scalpay.
The vessels had each a light in the mast. The
brobrother saw the light flash when coming in Caolas
Scalp.Scalpay – Alan then was lost – Ru huisnis &
Ru-balannis – A snow storm coming on the
brobrother thoutthought this was the cause of his losglosing the light or
that it drove hi Alan past – Miss C-Campbell had half
Scalp.Scalpay to herself. Died of dropsey. Her father
and brothers - Calum, Iain, Kenneth went
to America & Peigi & Barbara – this last marmarried
in Skye. Peigi marmarried in America a MacNab
belongbelonging to Islay. She was engengaged however to Capt.
Kenneth Campbell of Taransay. She & her
husband managed to come back & Capt Camp.
She lived at Rodail & then Capt Campl.
where her husband taught the school for a time
Capt Campbell then brotbrought them to Taransay
built them a house & gave her grazing for two cows.
Then they removed to Caolas Scalpay where
she died about 55 yrsyears ago near 80 yrsyears of age. She
was a tall straight stout no ardan (pride) hair
rich auburn – this the colour of all the family.

Scùile = Iron rig ring with a net for fishing lobster
used before creels. Scúmar = wooden hoop with
a net & handle used for taking up herrings falingfalling
from a net in taking into a boat. Scóp = Iron
ring with net & handle for fishing up
creachain clams.

A bhean odhar odhar an dorust a soghail
sa bhean bhui eadh bhuidheach a fhear gu fhear

Ugh aig eirig leanamh aig aimig is claclann
aig sgalaig

div.title: An Fhrithe

lg.l: Dia romham Dia nam dheoidhdheoghaidh
Mise eir a shlighe Dhia, 's Dia eir mo luirg
An t ora rinn Muire dha mac
Sa bheann Bride romh glaic
Fhic uthu sid a Righ nan Dul
S thuirt RRigh nan DDul gum bu cheart
Am fios a fhuair mi le fios firinn
Gun fhios breige gum faic mise na tha bhuam.

div.p:
This is to be said da lalatha na frithe – Di-
Daoirn & Diahaoine – moch is anmoch.
If a perperson is expected home for instance
it is a sign that he is well if you see a
person or beast coming to meet you both
of these two days. This was said when XCriosd was
lost – to his mother. Anything lost this is
said for it.

This is a plant – Fionn faoilteach –
which is pulled & carried to the ceart which
gives victory.

lg.l: BuainiBuainidh mise an earr-reidh
Eir chor s gum bi chaoinide mo bhlas
S gum bu bhathidebhlathaide mo chruth
Gum bu h-eilean eir muir mi
Gum bu charraige eir tir mi
S leonaileonaidh mise chuile duine
S cha leon duine mi
Bi buar.buarach shiod eir na h aighean laoilaoigh so
S bi buar.buarach shugain eir crocrodh na duchaduthcha
S bi buar.buarach ur eir na h-aighna h-aighean laoilaoigh so.
E hò muirneag a bhò si so a bho chinn
E ho gra an t aogh
Sa bho ghu sa bho dhudhubh
Sa ionnan galar dhomhs as duisduits
Tha mis thu ri call do laoilaoigh
S tha m aona mhac min fon mhuir
Fhaic uthu bho ad air an liana
San lalaogh boirean eir a bialabialamh

div.p:
Otters bring forth end of Sep.September or beg.beginning of OctOctober
two pups – a male & female each time.
In swimming about each pups go on each
side of dam. They eat muca-rua – eels
they prefer. They have the head half of the
eel & eat the tail half. They catch the
eel by the tail & allow it to drag the otter till
the eel gives up dead. The eel lives in a faicfaiche
in a cairn with a clear morghan in
front & round it. FaicFaiche = sloc under
a big stone in a sea cairn. The same
with the lobster.

The eel swims backwards against the
tail & is the only fish that does so except the lobster
when at speed. When going into a cairn he
goes a falgaran but when in a hurry th he
goes flap foremost. The eel may go into 6 or 7
creels ere it be caught because it comes out tail first.
A large eel caught at Airdabhorain took hold
of the tin bailer in the boat & went from end to end
to end of boat & kept it steady & found that way
till the folg.following day.

Lobster breed in faicfaiche in banks mileirich
s a chuan. Iuchair in them at all
times winter & well as summer. The
trosg casts the iuchair from Feb.February to March.
Lobster casts the shell in June. They get
scarce by 1st June & get plenty by middle
of July. The langa casts the iuchair by 5th
March also traille or manach (=trosg) am
Falmair (=haig) an Ŭgsa trosg all there
Never saw iuchair in the eel. The
bradan-seathan or turbaid in 5 MarMarch. The
ruithleis sticks to rocks – only on the west
side of Uist & washed off the rocks on
shore. A ghibneach comes from the
creachan – grows to 3 or 4 lbs. Mucrua or
creagag numerous in autumn. An carbhan-
ach only got in deep water. Suit-gharbh =
gold-fish. Ball dubh air an adaig
s earball fad air a chuideig. Cuideag or
gealag = Whiting. Liabag-chiar = Sole
Mac-laimheis or Clabciochrain or
cat-mara = mac-lamhaich = Sea-
cat. The bloidheag breeds in March & has
beautbeautiful cuilein red, lia & uaine. Corr
shiolag the large long siolag

A fish met Macleod GrimiseyGrimsay
fisherman out from Sloc-a-ro. Fish
sound mar rém na cuibhle & same
size as a spinning wheel. & thick. He
He put the clip in it & it straightened
the clip. supposed weight from 150 to 200.
Met this fistfirst in 1876. No eyes to be seen but
saw the breath coming. Not the cearban. It had a
piuthagan beaga beaga one wong working one
each side alternately.

Muc-shiolaig
like the siolaig came to Scarra-leoid
Iasg an riobain, the rioban falls from its nose.
Cloidheag a kittle fish to catch. Ruileis = a
thickest fish. Manach-sgúir – crooked nose & bites
hand size of cuddie.

GruanGruthan nam bodach, the liver is washed & put
in clean cold water & all.allowed to stand there for 3 or 4 hours
when it becomes nearly snow white. Then put in a
basin agus ga thaosnathaosnadh agus toirt as a chuile
riamhach a th ann. Then put putsputs a small
very grain of salt, soda & pepper & then oat
meal or bere & baked & put in a say a pudding
plate. Puts this in a pool of boiling water & if at
hand flounders soles Crog or Crog a bhaigean
or piece of cod or skate. Nearly an hour or ¾
takes out allows it to cool little warmer
than cold. Like butter them & delicious
2 put in the goile of the trost & used as a
marrag. The gruangruthan of the langa is stronger
again. first boiled like fish & then fried.
But only the liver of the ling with the iuchair is
safe. If the gruangruthan of a ling is taken it causes
for 3 days a heaviness & then the skin peels
of & casts. He is troubled with musgaid, ruai,
or trom or sac. The bradan leathan's gruangruthan
if with iuchar does the same. When the fishfisherman
wants a gruangruthan langa he puts a X of the
gruangruthan of the ling that has an iuchair. & upon
no account touches another.

Coral = Na Cridheacha cruadha
Found by Anthony Campbell Kentangval got 23
March cul Bhorisey and in 140 fath.fathoms much
more whole.

James Macneil mac Ghilleaspaic
Neill – got concord.concordance for the priest. BotBought two stones
in Ireland for £15. Belfast? He was going
about with the pair

Bradan brăthan = Turbot. Bradan leathanleathann =
Halibut

div.p:
Sponges small are found in May at B Trai-
chais Borve Barra. Small & beautbeautiful fine & read.

ComsumptionConsumption only in two families in Barra.
Was unknown within the memory of old people.
Liver of fish but little used in Barra.

div.title: Celtic Rune Cross
div.p:
Stood at head of tunag of Fearchar Johnson
who fled from Mull – he havghaving struck a man
there coming home frfrom a market & killed him.
Fled to Barra & remained there. Big & strong. He
was the first of Johnson that came to Barra – His iar
ogha left Barra with his 3 sons when he was 71
& lived 7 years in Cape Breton. Left 44 yrsyears ago.
None of the treubh left in Barra. Fearchar
himself built his own tunga & all his sucsucessors till the
treubh left Barra. (The stone in Caibeal
Mhore was sold aftafter having been stolen from for
two cows valvalued £50 each = £5) The cross
was the first leac seen in Kilbar.

Dun-nan-torr (from heaps of seaweed
left for boats there formerly – on the flat
ground only a flat heap now. Stones away
for buildgbuilding houses.

Rooks = Rocais-ean. OccOccasionally come to SSouth Uist
with e gairbhean of east wind & go with the
gaibhean of any other wind – in autautumn &
spring.

Taigh talamh on machair Kilphad.Kilpheadar.
a mound & high. Old John Martin (80) saw
the door open & was in a long distdistance Saw
ashes there – inside.

A Creàthach (Crabhach?) lived on the
poing going EEast of Cladh Hallinn & lived by
faith & prayer. Bha e g urnuigh a lalatha
s a dh-oichedh-oidhche & a faighfaighinn a bhith mar bhiodh
feum aige eir o am gu am. LaLathabha sin a
thainig e thun dorust na bothaig & thuirt e ris fhein –
An droch lalatha ors easeasan ris fhein. Cha rorobh sin tintighinn
an lalatha sin & duair thainig an oicheoidhche cha tig
sian eir & smaointsmaointich e gu de b aobhar. Chuir
air a chaint a thuirt e agus b aireach leis
e s thainig am biadh thuige. Ru-Hallan the
name of the place he lived in.

29/3/771877. Caibeal MhicCeallaich
out from Dallabruig close to the marsh of
KillpheadKillpheadar. On flattish rocks at low
water. 100 yrsyards from shore long reaches of
rafts & rocks with a depth of 1 fathfathom or so
betbetween them & shore. all the rocks encrusted
with iodine. Fine day – most suitable light ES.South on wind = No caibcaibeal
visible. Two old men only heard of such never
seen it. Rocks flat under water all round. On the
higher reefs lots of loose boulders or tangle
grown. Diff.Difficult to say where stood the caibeal. CladCladh
Pheadair is disused. Old John Martin saw the bid-
ean of the caibeal up. Nothing seen now.

The only stones called 'Caibeal MhicCeallaich' on
the N.North side of which long reach of ledges reefs full
of loose bouldboulders lying on flat rock & morghan
ghan

div.title: Rúideag
div.p:
A little bird size of blackbird twanytawny & red-
dish throat. Breeds on the border of the lake
W.West of Borinish.

Lorg a Bhaideanaich between
Lochboisdale & Caolas Staolay. Mark
of a foot with toes &c in the rock.

Cross with holes
at Kilbar was the brangas. There were 4
holes in cross – only 2 now seen. Thro these 4 holes
went the chain by which the criminal was
tied. There he stood for 3 Sundays days at the
door of the chapel.

Treas Bruth na h-Alba
An Crímcleit, Sithean a Chrimcleit
high & steep at Gearruithheille, S.South Uist
Close to this is Crois AltanAlltan an t-Sagairt with a
cross cut in the stone.

Gille guirmean = Falt ball got at
Clachan Cilldonnan.

Na Bardaibh near AbricAbriachan & Innse Bard
ChluainiChluainidh. Iobardan – all low lying places

John Macinnes ("Iain Mac Phadruig"), 74, Staoligearry S.South Uist
30 March 1877

div.title: LaoiLaoidh na h Ighne
div.p:
Gille bocbochd a ghabh gaol eir niannighean bheartbheartach
agus cha tug a daoine dha i s cha rorobh
cead aige suil thort orra. Mac giob
air a bha gaol eir nieannighean aluin uasail.
Dh fhag e 'n riocriochd s dh fhag a cealciall ise
s dh fhalbh i colacomhla ris na feigh gun
sgòth aodaodaich orra. Bhiodh i g ionailt colacomhla
ris na feidh sa cadal colacomhla s cha teich
adh as roimpe. Bhiodh i cadal nam
measg. Chuir ad a seo fios airson
fiach an tig a tur thuic agus shin
ad sin a tilgeadh. S iomaiomadh lalatha fhuair
e coramcothram a tilg ach cha tilg e idir orra
e cho gaolgaolach oirroirre. Bha a folt a sios gun
lar. Bha i na cadal ri taotaobh tolmain
sa lamh fo ceann eir an tolman s na
feifeidh mu cuairt di. Fhuair easan
ialadh a brebreith orra. Thug e dhachaidhachaidh i
Sin mar a thoisthoisich e ris an laoilaoigh.

lg.l: Fhuair mo leanleannan am chadal
'S mi gailgabhail fad.fadachd am urnuigh
S mi gun tuigse gun reusan
Gun neo fheumail an turn ad
S mi mar ghnoban aig garach
RiRigh gur narach a chuis e
Sid a ghit tha mi sireadh
Pairt do spiorad na h-uirghh-uirnigh
S a dhia mhor tha nad chairchathair
Rinn Rinn do mhathas na uair domh
S mi air fasfasach a mhunaimhunaidh
S do bhunas bhlas a cumail an fhuar uam
S iomaiomadh roid tha nad fheartaifheartaibh
Gu feoil a Phear a ghluas
Sa Dhia mun cuir thu san lic mi

i. Chaochail mac a ghiobair as a

agus chuir ad car mu cheile
eir gach taobh an chladh. GhearGhearr
a cuideacsecuideachdse na craoibh & dh fhas

An fheodhainfheodhainn bha gearra nan craocraobh

buird ri cheile s as a cheile cha tigtigeadh ad.

div.p:
Donald Macintire ("Donul Mac Neill") 84
Howbeag S.South Uist 6th April 1877.
div.title: Hough-moire.
div.p:
Bha an sluagh a falbh & bhathas a faicfaicinn
boir.boireannach eir deirdeireach oirre. ChaiChaidh bean a sin
agus chuir i a cuigeal crosgag san
uaigh agus thuirt i rithe nach leigleigeadh i as
a sid ei gus an innsinnseadh e de an t aoraobhar
i bhibhith eir dheirdhireadh. Tha mise nieannighean do
RiRigh LochlanLochlann agus nin nam chois.
s tha ad gam chumail eir dheirdheireadh
& ach leig us staistaigh mi dha m uaigh
s chachan eireirich mi tuille. Bhathadh eir
saothach le m athar mi agus tuatuath eir
linn na faolach tha 3 staimh dhuighdhiubh
a fas romh an trung againn
gus e lan oir us airgairgid us leor. On
chuir thusa a cheist rium s leat
an trung'. Thug aan sin a bhean a chuig
bharr na h-ughh-uaigheach s chaichaidh nieannighean RiRigh LLochlainn
a sios s cha d fhalbh i ris an t sluaisluaigh
tuilltuilleadh. Dh-innis a chailchailleach dha a
bodbodach mun oir. ChaiChaidh e gu
iar. Thainig e dhachadhachaidh a chead lalatha
s cha mhor nach do mharbh
e chailchailleach chionn bhi g innse an
tulla bhriag dha. An dara lalatha do.
An treas lalatha fhuair e na tri staimh
& lia'aganliathagan a fas romh an trung & bha or
us iundas aig a bhod.bhodach sa chailchailleach riamh
tuilletuilleadh.

Duke of Tarentum came abtabout43}5 yrsyears ago. When he came to sight
of Faoghail Hough he said A this is the
river my fathfather told me he used to be a
breacach. There was a crowd & he
went up & kisskissed an old man & said
O seo m'athair – Seo Maceachain
& Neill do sons of the two brothers –
RaolRaghnall was Alex.Alexander's son. Gave £20
to the old man. £20 to his sistsister Isabel
Nic RaolRaghnaill nic Fir Houbig. Gave also
£20 to John Maceachain IocarIochdar. He
sent £20 to eaeach of the two first while
he lived. Took full of a stocking of earth
from TotaTobhta na Bracha below which
is Am Mùr on the flat near the river.

lg.l: X An ainm an AthAthar sa MhMhic san SpSpioraid Naoimh
N. Lai mise an nocnochd s lailaigh Dia liom.
Cha mhumhutha lailaigh s mise leis an olc
S cha mhu laislaigheas an t ololc liom.
A DhDhia nam feart dion mi nocnochd
Na diobair mi o d mhuintearsmhuinntearas
Nach urra mi nocnochd ga chuineachadhchuimhneachadh
Aig mheud nan loclochd a rinrinn mo chobh
Nach uraurra mi nocnochd ga chuineadhchuimhneachadh

div.p:
Duke of TartTarentum middle sized clear mindminded
smart man high sight – Swarthy
complex.complexion About 5-10 or 5-11.

Came to Uist abtabout 46 years aog. Left 10£ a year to his
cousincousins AlastAlastair & Isebel each as long as they lived.
His nephew a count along with him. He had 2
sistersisters. Had one son – No English – I cant speak
to you but Ill send you my son. He then got
an English tutor to his son. The son died & the
proproceedsclaimed by a man frfrom America.

RaolRaghnall had a son John who had a son Tonas
who was a cooper in the Customs IIn Greenock
who had a son Thomas who went to Quebec.
Probably this was the claimant. he came
to Paris to see the Duke who behaved kindly
to him. Duke sharp – knew his relatives
by sight. He wldwould be abtabout 70 or 75. The late
Angus Fletcher EdinEdinburgh correspcorresponded with him.

Angus Macintire & KenthKenneth Beaton
were taken away from Croic Pheigh.Pheighinn
Paton was put out at Assynt & money
given him to take him home. MacintMacintire
was keunpr in France 15 yrsyears & came
back to Uist.

Rev Duncan Robertson (?) was the name
of the Episcopal minister who was drowned
on Ath-na-dise (of two) Baileshear some
200 years ago or thereby.

"Mairi Bhoidheach"
was the daughtdaughter of Rev. Alan MacCuinn
son of Rev. Daniel MacCuinn, Taigh
earry. Song composed by Alexander
Stewart a schoolmaster. Kept the
school at Baileanloch – the only one
in N.North Uist at the time. Stewart was
alleged to have used some familiarity
with some of his female pupils which
whether founded or unfounded caused
a feeling against him & he left. The
children of the best people in N.North Uist at-
tended his school Miss Mary MacCuinn
(Nic Cuinn) was one in his school, and She
took sl such a dislike to the man that
she could never bear to hear the song. She
died some some 15 years ago or so – aged
She was a very tall handsome portly
woman of mild benevolent disposition.
Stewart left Uist about the year 1800.

Sornach Coir-Fhinn Langas
NNorth Uist is an irregular circle in one
place 38 ydsyards x 30. One stone 7 ftfeet high stands
in the oval point about due S.South and about
4 ftfeet within line of circle. Many other stones
still stand in the circle round though
many are fallen. Between the upright
a rude wall is built. The circle stands
on side of hill on a terrace facing the S.South.

Neill Macpherson, Pauper, Lianacleit
Benbecula is aged 95. Had 9 daughters
8 of whom married. Had 57 grandchildren
and 20 great grandchildren – in all 80 –
and if he lives five more years he may
see his great great grandchildren
– his ion-ogha (iar-ogha ogha – mac – mise.
In December last there were in Ben-
becula 6 men & 1 woman upwards of
90 years of age. 3 of these died since.

Neill Macpherson remembers
an occurrence when he was only 4 yrsyears
old. A woman – a friend of his sister
was coming from N.North Uist to Benbecula
She took passage in a boat coming
to fish the cearban – sun-fish – which
had a station on Fuitheidh Benbecula.
They left Lochmaddy & at mouth of loch
they purpursued the cearban & struck it. The
fish halted not till it reached RuRubha
Rusnis – a distdistance of some 25 or 30 miles.
The fish contcontained 7 barrels of gnuthan. Landed
on Fuithey & the woman got across
from Island by people working at Ceilp.

The cearban was fished regularly at
reotharst naCarrigeis. Maclean who built
the CearsavaCearsavagh House Lochmaddy had
a boat or boats engaged in the business
& it was on his boat the woman came
over. The boat was coming to its station
at Fuiey – When the cearban is found
sleeping on surface the gatha chearbain
is thrust into it after which it goes to the
bottom to rub itself where it still more
drives the gath barb into its shoulder.
It then comes to the surface & sets off
towing the boat after it till it fairly
becomes exhausted – When it it is spear-
ed with sleagh a chearbain – a three
edged long spear with long handles like
that of a hay fork. That killed at Moriff
contcontained 6 barrells of gnuangnuthan. Steamers are
supposed to be the cause of the absence
of the Sun-fish.

Singil, Singileadh = Biadhadh = Placing sea-
weed in the drill for manure. Harris
. Am Bùite = Puffin. Diurite = giuran = shellfish
in wood from which comes the buite. {LamhaiLamhaid {Guillemot = gob birbiorach
fearri-breac. Cearc-Scràbaire used to breed in North
end of Scarp – not now – supposed to breed there still
Has an ugly scriach – Fachach

The Buanbhuachille breeds on Loch uis-
iadar Loch Leatha Loch bheinniseal – on
islands there – in Beanntaibh Harris
streams come down from these to the sea.
DonDonald Maclean Scarp when a boy herding there
saw the old birds with the two little young
often there & often chased them among
stones & water – In July. Tis the Learga?

Cinn rang urlair = Timber in a boat. Rang
ais = taobh shlat. Puthag = Pilot fish or small whale

Cearban, Harris: Old men only saw one female
– all males. one female the only one – had 12 barrels
oil. Generally from 7 to 9 barrels.

Drafag = Fornication, Rinn e n drafag oirre
= He made fornication with her.

Flora Macdonald & Prince Charlie left Rois-
nis was it not Loch aoineart. She lived at KildonanainKildonan.

S. Brenden the Elder died 16 May18 Life in MS.
Cottonian Library.

Cnaiseag = Sedimentary dross as Cnaiseg
a ghuail – Smithy dross Cnaiseag geire
gnuthain = of tallow, liver.
Muig a choinneal = Snuff the candle.

Sithein Chrimcleit Gearyheille Tuesday
8 May 1877 is a large knoll composed
of large boulders grass grown on a rock
plain – evidently natural – thithough called
Treas Sithein na h-Alba - Cr Very
rough boulder like knoll. Sithean a Chrimc
leathad is the name.

Crois an t-Sagairt is a natural cross
in a big boulder with a square perperpendicular front
& level top. A depression on top serves
as a tobar coisruigte. The pristpriest house
stood from 100 to 150 ydsyards due north.
When Sine ni MhicNeil Barra
came to Gearryhille she got the land and
the pristpriest left. The site of her house is
still seen where she reared the Major.
She was the last Macneill born at Cios-
mal. The rudharubha was so fertile that
every sheep had 3 lambs & every lamb 3 lambs
the folgfollowing year.

On opposite side is RudhRubh Hallan
& Dun RuRubha Hallan.

Dun Dhallabrig – On this stood the
Catholic chapel ere removed to its prestpresent
site. This was a large dun.

AlexAlexander Walker Gearyhille saw the walls
of Caibeal Mhic Ceallaich at Laig
an t Saile. From 7 to 8 ftfeet of walls
still up when I saw it 28 yrsyears ago. The
lintel was still on one windwindow & others
may have been but much of the place
was a heap with sea weed & tangle massing
over – Only the top of wall visible during low
spring tide.

When men were disputdisputing about march
between Barra & SSouth Uist where to mark their
march they saw a man standing at Aird
Mhic Cuanain at Cairval. They made
the march there. The man is seen
there sometimes yet. Sometimes he
speaks & tells of the future.

Flora Macdonald datdaughter ninnighean RaoilRaghnaill ic
AonaisAonghais oig ic RaoilRaghnaill ic AilenAilein. AonasAonghas Og
a celebrated soildiersoldier. he & RaolRaghnill Mor mac
ic Shir Seumas Morair DonullDomhnullach

lg.l: Ogh AonisAonghais og nam brat.bratach
As RaoilRaghnaill mhor nam feacananfeachdanan
Be sgeula cruaicruaidh nan tachradh e
Us n eascairdean thinthighinn slan.

div.p:
She was born at Frobost fo dheas where
her fathfather had land. When he died she
livelived with her uncle AonasAonghas mor Fear
AiriAiridhAiri-mhuillin – his son AonasAonghas Og
was when he retreturned frfrom the American War
where he disdistinguished himself greatly built the hohouse
at AriAiridh Gearrybhailteas & marmarried a daughsistsister of
AlastAlastair (grandson of AlastAlastair mor), Boisdale
Col Alex.Alexander Macdonald. AonasAonghas og was
a most distdistinguised sol.soldier & could swim 2 miles
thothough drowned at Lochaoineart.

Uistean Ban Chillepheadair came frfrom
N.North Uist – His son Donald lived at Dall
brug & was the father of the late Bean Orm
acleit (Mrs Maclellan)

div.title: Birnie's tyranny.
div.p:
John Maclellanmillan skipper Dallabrog
tentenant lent £10/ to a neighbour who was to repay
him at the first market in summer.
But not having done so & aftafter trying for
25: or 36 years to get it he saw the man
before small debt court. On the morning
of the court while skating on the ice in front
of the house a son of John Macmillan
fell & broke his collar bone &c. This rendered
the fathfather's appappearance in court 10 minsminutes late & decrdecreed
was brotbrought out against him with £5 more
than he lent the man. The acctaccount was made
up no person knew how but without
foundation (The Macleans of Mull
had only Eachann us Eoun 'The acctaccount made
up like this.) John Macmillan showed the
decree to the fiscal & asked him how he coudcould
obtain a rehearsrehearsal of the case & place the shoe
maker on oath about this extra accaccount. The
fiscal said the decree was absolutely
worthless & wholly illegal. This came to Birnie's
ear & when paying the rent he attattacked Macmillan
& aftafter damning & callg.calling him everything for showing
his decree to the fiscal darg.daring him to have his
decision reversed by the sheriff Mac or that
he wldwould put him out of his croft. Should you
put me of out of Uist & out of the Kingdom
I who know the truth of the case will not
submit to such a decdecree till I bring the case
before the sheriff. Mr Birnie rose from the
the side of the room walked across it &
struck Macmillan in the cheek in presence of his clerk!

When Cailein Ruadh LeoghaisLeodhais died
100 sheep 100 pigs 100 hens, 100
geese 100 ducks 1000 fat heifers & 100 casks of whiskwhisky
were consumed at the funeral which
lastlasted three days & three nights.

Sóll = Broken shellfish welkswhelks limpets
sgilleach-fionntrain thrown out for bait.
Slugag = The broken little hollow in this tis
pounded.

Clacharan an Fhraoich = Stone-chat. The
stonechat here is the wheat ear.

A Mheribh bheag 21st May 1877 – Monday
Took punt – lots of men girls &boys.
Lots of glas-fhaoileag's nests butter cups
& wild Kail. Small rock scarcely any grass
on S. E.South East corner a place like this
PerpPerpendicular hole about 4 ftfeet deep long 8 ftfeet long
Rough sketch of rock water

In Berie-mhor full of lux-blue by cruth & Am Boid-muc
lus-nan-deargnag & on the N.North side fine bush
of mount-ashmountain-ash beautbeautiful soft downy moss & heath
isle about 50 ydsyards long & 20 wide.

Leac-Ba-sionna a cist on east side Beinn
Langaish – Ba-sionna nam (?! of person
buried –

Dun-Una built as a tearmadas to Una
ninnighean RiRigh LochlanLochlann when they were being
sgiursed away from here.

Barp Langaish is a monument
of to a Righ LochlanLochlann. Stones taken from
bord an loch – no stone there now that
can be moved – Mrs Murdoch Mac
Asgail an observant woman saw 40 yrsyears
ago the stone circle proprotuding high some 4 or
5 ftfeet now only an arc.arched top is seen.

Pobull nan Gillean at Langaish
now nearly under moss.

Pappey Sheiley mhor HHarris – Thursday 31 May 1877
Crib abtabout 3½ x 3 x 2 ftfeet high. irregulirregular oval
rough linteled over as like the rock on
which it is. 4 of these more or less perfect
among rough stones on N.North cairn sheer
above the foaming sea – Eilean an Stàoin
small isle cut off 2 square sidesides Rough sketch of island

On top of Sheilley a triangtriangular bould.boulder, 11 x 11 x 10
and abtabout 4 ftfeet deep. Rests on 2 extrextruding sides, 4
easily rocks. Smooth on ununder side rock
mostmostly quarz & gneisgneiss rough on which it rests
BouldBoulder gneiss. Weighs perperhaps 40 or 50 tons.
diagram of rock Bits of rock in situ smooth & even
Stone smooth below – 4 or 4½ ftfeet deep.
W.West nearly flat atop. Nearly on the
top of hill perhaps 300 ftfeet above sea
level. Striation of rock underneath bouldboulder
N.W.North West & S.E.South East – no compass.

In a On a projecting preprecipice -near by a pair of
peregrines stood & on my appapproach they rose screamgscreaming
wildly & wheeling & hovering over us & occoccasionally swoop
ing down in the most daring manner.
I could distdistinctly see their black whiskers & eyes.
I wish I could have got at their nest
but no time.

Got nonumber eggs in Sheiley – only one grey gulls. Got
two eider nests with 3 eggs each in Sheiley bheag –
- a high heap of rock with some grass
atop. Left Sheiley about 8.30 pm with
a slight head wind & Strong head tide – AftAfter
beating backwards & forwards numerous
times left Papey to leeward of us just in the dark
– blowing strongly frfrom the E EEast – boat short of balstballast
Got to Caolas SgairSgairidh & with one reefsreef in the fore-
sail & leading easy wind for ½ to ¾ hour the
boat gained not 20 yrdsyards blowing hard. Got
to Ensey house at 12.40 just ere the servants
had retired.

Peat Cutting on Fuday is disliked as
in that case the peats are burnt about
a corpse.

Carran = plant with a long leaf
Caigeal = Shallow creek with narrow opening
Geiltean = Fish gills.
Tor an Tòthan – Small moss grown heap
Sgeot = Recess in a rock

Fear gun each gun eathar s fad a shalshail
ri talamh.

lg.l: Te bha blithean ba aig Ru Ru-Rubha Huisnis
Cha'n fhaigh Mac iain Ghiorr a Muil thu
Ho ro muirneag thu
NighNighean na ba ghoid e'n urraiurraidh
Ho ro muirneag thu.
Ogha Chiaru 's iar-ogh Du'aig (Cruinneig?)
Horo muirne ag thu.

div.p:
Bha Mac Iain Ghiorr ga h-eisdeach-eiseachd
agus d'uair bha ise ullamh bhuail e bhuar-
ach eir a bho. Leum Mac Iain Ghiorr agus
ghabh e mu chuil na ba agus sguab thug e leis i!
Mŏthir = Noise of wave wave.

lg.l: Da cheann a dh-fagdh-fhag an t-earrachal
ChaiChaidh iad eir thearmad an mhointich
Cailltear mise gun fhios dusa
Caillt.Cailltear thusa gun fhios domhsa.

div.p:
Beannach.Beannachadh Iain ic Fhearchair d uair
chaichaidh e choinnchoinneamh Mac AonaisAonghais Ghobha – caraid
dileas dha fhein. Bha iad le cheile fuireach
ann am mointich – Mac Fhearchair
ann am moineachmointeach Ebhall agus am fear
eile ann an Cill-éirebhagh Beinn am faothla.

lg.l: Bod.Bodach Bhearnasdail an Unais Innis
Duine s grainde tha san t siorract siorrachd
Ceann-fine gach dèisdin
Tha do ghruaighuraidh gun aona mhir bithidh
ColtColtach ri bian bbeisde duiduibh
Do chom lacanlachdann cartaicartaidh ruighinn
Ga ruidheadh eir deile –
Tha do cheann urrad ri cruachbrig mhoine
Do chluas urrad ri lòban
Tha do bhial urrad mar gum biodh òbar

Le graine eorneorna eir leighinn (Floor on which
the quern sits) Obar = what holds the corn.
Amhach chaol na corra-ghri'ichcorra-ghrithich
Ni uthu fhastfhathast cainb a ruitheadh
Croich a feuitheamhfeitheamh ort na suith
GheoGheobh na fithfithich feast ort!

div.p: Octànn = 1/8 of a peck.

Gille na Ciotaig a native of South Uist – Travelled
about with a pony. In Skye tied his pony to a door while he
went in. The pony got loseloose & went in to the corn & was poinded
& would not be freed till the poind was paid. The GGille na CiotgCiotaig
put down a the half on the gate of the poind and then sang
this aoir. Bod.Bodach Bhearnasdal begbegged and prayed him to take
back his half crown & never to repeat his aoir.
Gille na ciotaig lived at Lochboisdale or Loch
aoineart S.South U.Uist

Sclopach = The Soft baggbagged sea-weed. Roc = Langadal.
Smŏt = Light kind of red sea-weed short & feathery

div.title: Curious Names
div.p:
Torrlach a man's name in Harris and in
Skye – in both places descended of the same man.
Tirfail = "Dŏrsody" woman's name in Harris
– one woman there of this name.
Connaich – womans name Harris.
The mother lost was losing all her children and
when shes was with child again a guth
voice came to her and requested her to give
this name to the female child air a giulan and
that she would live. When the woman
was delivered she gave this name to the
child and the child lived – Connaich.
Bhorgach = Vorcanda Woman Harris
Beanti = Sophia. Slainte = Selina.
N N uair bha am boirionnach agus
leanadhleanabh air a h-iomachain thainig
guth a thubhairt rithe – Thoir Conn-
aich (Comhnaich?) air an lean-
adhleanabh nighinne tha air do ghiùlan.

Gille na Ciotaig was a native of North
Uist but having satirized a the factor or
proprietor there for some act of oppression
he was obliged to leave the place. He went to
South Uist and lived at Lochaoineart or
Lochboisdale – uncertain which – . He
travelled much about throughout the
Highlands and Islands and being highly
connected being a near relation of Lord
Macdonald he had access to the best society
in his travels. He travelled on horseback.

Upon one occasion when going through
Bearnasdail in Skye he called at a
friends house and tied his pony at the door.

The pony broke loose and found his way into
the corn of the tacksman of Bearnasdail,
a miser and a churl. The poet's pony
was poinded and when the poet came
out he found his pony poinded and
would not be released except upon pay-
ment of the damage – miastadh, domail –
done by him to the corn of Fear Bhearnas-
dail. Gille Na Ciotaig put down the half
crown on the wall of the poind – the legal
mode – and got his pony. He then
sang or recited the following satire
which so stung the miserly tacksman
that he begged him to take up his half-
crown and never to repeat his satire,
and besides that he was welcome to
cuid oicheoidhche us lalatha to himself and his
gearran whenever he came the way.

The poet, however, would not be
thus silenced and he left singing the
satire as he went his way.

div.p:
They gave the CaisnCaisein CallgCallaig to the wife & if she
took it they got some. If she was churlish & refused
they went out & went with a molmollachd an tighe.

The rann is unfit to print. (trick foot or tail
or head)

div.p:
Barran = Lockjaw. The old people applied
a plaid, poulticepoultice of naogh naogh boiteanan
(nine nine 9 x 9) earthworms for the cure of lock
jaw. The poulticpoultice was applied to the throat.

Fionn-faoilteach, a plant pulled and
carried to the ceart court, and which in
sures victory.

Capar} = Caput = head. i e Capar-coill bird of the wood
the p bird of the wood. Head bird of the wood.

div.p:
A Lewis man scolded his neighbours herd thus –
A rogaire! a mhic an rogaire! ogha an rogaire!
agus iar ogh agus ion-ogh an rogaire agus mar
biodh tu aig an rogaire cha bhiodh tu aig
an rogaire.

div.title: Daoine Sith – Sithichean
div.p: D

D uair nach biodh leanabh a tighinn thuige
theireadh iad gun robh e sna cniccnuic agus bha
iad a creidsincreidsinn nam fagadh iad an leanabh
meatmiotachd anns an crichcrioch eadar dha bhaile gu'n
tigeadh na sithichean agus gum fagadh
iad an leanabh ceart. Chaidh so a dhian-
amh lathair fear athrisaithris na sgeuil so – Iain
Macleod croitear Bhaltos Uig LeothasLeodhas 6/5 1874

Bha duine meatmiotachd ann am Bearnaraidh
Bheag an Leodhas ris an cante Lachlan mac
Iain ic Tharmaid ic AonasAonghais mhoir. Bha e fas
mor ach cha robh e taddad de dh-fheum ann, ach
de bha ann ach sitheach. Chunnaic fear sithich
agus labhair i riuriutha ann an iomadaidh cainnt ach
cha do fhreagair iad e. Ach mu dheireadh thall
labhair an duine riuriutha ann aman GailigGaidhlig agus
fhreagair iad ann an GailigGaidhlig e. Dh-fheoraich e
dhiudhiuth sa an ann aca bha Lachlan agus thubhairt
gur ann agus a steach a thug iad do chnoc
gun tuilidh guth no iomraidh.

div.title: Daoine Sith
div.p:
Bha duine toir dhachaidh mhonach 's an
anamoch mar bha ioma duine coir roimhe.
D uair a bha chliabh lan thuirt e ris feinfhein
Is truagh a nis nach robh neach agam a
thogadh an cliabh orm. Cha luaith a thubh-
airt e na fhuair e mar a mhiannaich e.
Thubhairt fear a chleibh – Co so a thog orm an
mo chliabh? Thog ars a sitheach fear a bhios
deonach do chuideachadh anns gach cas
cruaidh an tachair thu a bhith." Is maith
an naigheachd Arsa fear a chleibh. Tha
taigh agam ri dheanamh agus b fhearrde
mi comhnadh. Thainig grunnd shithichean
agus thog iad an taigh agus cha robh iad fein fada ris.
Ach mu bha fear an taighe riamh ann an
cruaidh chas cha s ann a nis airson luc-comainluchd-comain
bha e nis ann an cas bu chruaidh aisonairson nach
robh obair aige dha na daoine thaine dhach-
aidh agus dh-fheumadh e obair a chumail
riu. Na eigin chaidh e chun seann duine bha
s a bhaile feuch gu de bu choir dha dhean-
amh. Thuirt an seann duine ris Iarr orra
ceanglaichean a chur air an taigh agus ceangal
fiodhaig (wild fig) a chur air gach ceann
deth. Nan deanadh iad so cha b urrb urrainn iad fein
buaidh sam bith a bhith ac air an taigh.

Dhiult na sithichean siud a dheanamh
a muigh no mach agus thubhairt iad ris mur
an robh tuilidh obair aige dhaibh gun dean-
amh iad siud is so air. Dh-iarr an seann
duin air mar a {deanamh cuireadh iad ceangail fiodh-
aig air da cheann an taighe e shireadh orra
sugan ceann ordaig a dheanamh de'n ghain-
eamhaich ghlain airson tuodhtughadh don taigh.

Dh-fheuch iad ris a so a dheanamh ach
dhubh-dh-fhairtlich orra. Bha'n traigh sa
mhadainn mhoich mar gum biodh i air a treobh-
adh bho thaobh gu taobh. D uair chaidh
so an uachdar orra dh-fhag iad e agus a mach
a thug iad ag radh – Soraidh leat fein ach
mile mallachd aig beul t ionnsuich.

div.title: Damhsa Sith
div.p:
Bha fear a dol seachad air cnoc le buideal
air a mhuin. Chunnaic e dorus bruth sith
agus a bheul fosgailt agus na sithich a danns
is taigh ann a bhruth. Chaidh an duine steach
agus thoisich e air dannsa leis na sithich
agus am buideal air a mhuin. Bha an
duin air chall agus cha robh a bheo no mharbh
ri fhaighinn shios no shuas thall no bhos.
An ceann bliadhna chaidh coimhearsnach
dha an rathad agus chunnaic e am bruth fosg-
ailt agus na sithich a dannsadh agus a seat-
adh agus a ruidhleadh air an urlar agus
fear a bhuideil nan teis meadhoin agus
am buideal air a mhuin. Chaidh an
coimhearsnach a staigh agus thubhairt e ri fear
a bhuideil A charaid tha thìd agad sgur da d
dhannsa a dhuine. Thubhairt fear a bhuid-
eil nach robh fathast nach robh cocho fada sin
bho na thoisich. Cha do shaoil e bhliadhna
dhannsadh anns a bhruth ach mar ghreiseig
do latha!

div.title: A Phiob Shith
div.p:
Bha phiob gu tric agus gu minicminig air a
cluinntin s a bhruth-shith. Bhiodh puirt
shiubhlach shuigeartach aig na sithich anns
a bhruthain agus iomadaidh fonn aurainorain So fear dhiudhiubh –

lg.l: Am faic thu Nic dhuinn leis a chrodh laoigh
Am faic thu Nic dhuinn leis a chrodh laoigh
Am faic thu Nic dhuinn leis a chrodh laoigh
Ris a chrodh-laoigh s i na h-onar.

div.title: Treabhadh
div.p:
Bha duine treabhadh taobhfaisg sithein agus d-uair
a thainig e faisg air taobh an t-sithein chual e
guth anns a bhruthain ag radh – A Dhomhnuill
duinn a Dhomhnuill duinn fuirich thall fuir-
ich thall rainig do chrom-nan gad fadas nas leoir!
Ghabh Domhnall Donn anam feagal agus cha
tainig e na b fhaisg air a chnoc!

div.title: Sitheach an sliochd Leanabh Beag
div.p:
Bhiodh na sithich tric agus minicminig togail leoleotha
leanabain agus a fagail an cloinn feinfhein nan
aite. Is ann uaith so a theirear ri neach air
nach bheil coltas treamanta slan – Tha thu
anns na cnuic. Is tu tha s na cnoic

Thugadh leanabh mar so air falbh bho
na mnathan coimheadachd agus dh-fhag-
adh sitheach beag na aite. An ait a bhi
fas is ann a bha an leanabh a sior chrionchrionadh
agus a cnamh agus a dol as. Bha e ag ol agus
ag itheadh gun fhois gun tamh agus gun
ran a dol a chraos. agus e Bha e na champar
agus na chrois dha n teaghlach agus gun fhios
bho thalamh an t-saoghail gu de dheanamh
iad ris. Dh-athnich mu dheireadh an t seana
bhean gur h-e bha aic sitheach agus nach
b'e a leanabh fhein. Tilg ors ise anns an
abhuinn e agus gheibh thu do leanabh fein.
Rinn am boirionnnach mar a shir an t seann
bhean oireoirre agus thilg i an leanabh 's an abh-
uin an sitheach. Cha luaith a thug an sith-
each plub san abhuin na thainig a leanabh
fhein chun a bhoirionnnaich. Chuireadh na sithich
air ais a chlann mar a bheireadh iad leo iad
gu bog balbh gun mhothachadh gun fhair-
eachadh do neach air bith gun suil gam faicinn
Uaith so thainig am facal – 'Togail muintirmuinntir
Fhionnlaidh ort!'
Bha aig bean eile leanabh sitheach an ait
a leanabh fhein. Cha robh ire no piseach a
tighinn air an 'leanabh' ach a sior dhol as
agus gun an ran a cheann gun stad air
a chraos. Thuirt am boirionnach ris la bha
sin. 'A Mhoire mhuire tha mi seachd searbh sgith
dhiot.' Moire mu tha ors easan agus e ga
freagar nan deanamh tu run math riumsa
bheirinn faochadh duit agus dheanainn
gresgreis dhannsaidh dhuit. Thubhairt am boir-
ionnach ris gun deanamh. Siud an sithachsitheach
air an lar na bhodachan beag sgiobalt a
boganaich air an urlar. D uair bha e sgith
dannsaidh agus boganaich bocachaidh air
lar thainig e air ais na h-uchd. Dh-innis am
boirionnach da duine mar a thachair. Comh-
airle bheirinn ort os easan leine mhor chur-
ain a chur air am maireach agus a chur
a dhannsadh mar a rinn e 'n de agus tig
d uair bhios e sgith bogadaich lig san teine
Rinn i so mar a dh iarr an duin oireoirre.
Siud a mach an dorus an sitheach a
ranaich agus cha luaithe a bha no thainig
a leanabh fhein thuicesa.

div.title: Na Sithich A Treabhadh
div.p:
Bha croitear coir sgith le obair an earraich
mar a bha iomaiomadh duine coir roimhe. Thubhairt
e lalatha ris fhein an diugh tighinn dachaidh Is
truagh nach robh luchd cuidich agam. Cha
luaith a thubhairt na thainig luchd cuidich
gu leoir agus barrachd. Bha treabh aig
ullamh s a mhaduinn. Dh-fhuirich aon
do'n luchd cuidich airson cumadh tuarasdail
a dheanamh ris an duine. Is e an tuarasdail
a dh iarr e sguab air sgath a chuile fear
bha aig ag obair. Air so chord iad. Bha naodh
cruachan arbhair aige d uair thainig am
foghair. Thainig na sithichean air toir an
tuarasdail. Thog gach fear leis sguab air a
ghualain gus na thog iad leo gach uile h-aon
sguab a dh-fhas daibh da. D uair a chun-
naic an duine gun robh iad toir leo a chuile
h aon sguab a dh fhas da shuidh e air
raoid agus thachais e cheann 's gun fhios aig
air uachdar an t saoghail gu de dheanamh
e. Bha aon sitheach gun sguab agus d uair
a chunnaic an duine so rug e air an
raoid agus thilg e asna dheigh i. Uaith so theirear
'Co lion'arlionmhor ri muinntir Fhionnlaidh'

div.title: Sithichean Cnoc-mor Arnoil
div.p:
Bha sithichean a Chnoic mhoir agus teaghlach
a bha faisg air nan nabaidhean math co-
maith agus gum bitheadh iad le cheile deas-
achaidh am bithidh anns an aon choire. Is
ann do mhuinntir tir nam fear beo a bhuin-
eadh an coire. Bhiodh na sithich a tighinn air
a thoir co tric agus a bhiodh feum ac air agus
bhiodh sin tric gu leoir agus ga chur dachaidh
a rist d uair bhiodh iad ullamh dheth.

D uair rachadh muinntir tir nam beo air
toir a choire dh-fheumadh iad a rath ri muinn-
tir a bhruth -

lg.l: Dlithe gobha gual
Gu iarrunn fuar a ghoil bhrich
Is dlithidh coire cnaimh
Sa chur slan da thaigh

div.p:
LaLatha de na laithean /laibhibh/ dhithchuimh-
nich bean taigh a choire na briathran
a radh ris na sithichean d uair thog iad
leoleotha nan coire. Thug na sithich so fa near
agus cha do chuir iad an coire dachaidh
na am. D uair a chunnaic am boirionn-
ach nach do chuir na sithich dachaidh an
coire mar bu ghnath leoleotha chaidh i air a
thoir dha'n bhruth. Bha dorus a bhruth fosg-
ailt air a cinn chionn b e oicheoidhche Shamh-
na i. Ch Ghabh am boirionnach a steach
gu bog balbh agus gun fhacal a radh
no failt a chur sgriob i leatha an coire
le ruaim. Cha do chord so ris na riuthsa
D uair bha i dol a mach doruas a bhruth
thubhairt fear dha na sithich –

lg.l: A bhean bhalbh a bhean bhalbh
A bhean bhalbh a bhean bhalbh
Thainig oirnn a tir nam maibhmarbh
A thug leatha an coire le chruth

div.p:
Fuasgail an dubh (dul?) s leig an Dearg
Dol a steach doruas a taighe feinfhein rug
an cull cu sith oireoirre air cul a sàlach
agus ghear e i dona dona. Cha ghabh-
adh an lot a rinn an cu sith stad a chur
air agus thraigh am boirionnach air fuil.

div.title: Sithichean Cnoc na Connlaich
div.p:
Bha fear a dol seachad da chnoc na connlaich
feadh na hoicheoidhche le connlaich chon fodraidh
a chruidh. D uair bha e direach eadar an
da chnoc chonnlaich chual e guth as a chnoc ag radh ris –
A mhic Dhomhuill ghlais nach fag thu
am fodar! Fhreagair guth as a chnoc air an
taobh eile dheth ag radh – A mhic DhomhaillDhomhnaill
ghlais cha'n fhag thu am fodar am fads
agus a bhitheas uiread leat agus a tha na d'
aghaidh agus {fear{duine a bharrachd!

div.title: Sithichean Sithein Chaiplig
div.p:
Bha duine dol seachad air Sithean Chaiplig
lalatha teathteth samhraidh agus chual e mīstreadh
a staigh 's a chnoc agus mu chuala shanntaich
e deoch bhlathach a bhi aige agus am pathadh
mor ga sharachadh. Is truagh ors easan
ghlugain nach robh mo bhaltradh air bean a ghlugain.
Shaoil an duine nach luaithe a thuirt
e so nach chunnaic e bean chaol chōt
uaine tighinn thuige le cuach bhlathaich
So ars a bhean shith so dhuit deoch. An
Dia ghabh an duine sgath agus thuirt e, Cha
ghabh a bhean a cha n eil feum sam bith
agam air oireoirre. Mur a bheil ors ise cha
bu choir dhuit iarraidh. Cha n eil mi air
son an deoch a ghabhail idir ors eise. Am
bheil eagal ort ors ise gun dean e cron
duit? ort? Tha ors eise. Galar na te
a chuir a cheud chìr Cheudaoin na
ceann ormsa ma ni e {dad{tad orts. Ciod
an galar tha sin ors eise. Tha ors ars ise
Galar gun mhac gun nighean gun ogha gun iar ogha

'Bho aoin gu anmhuinn'. Chaidh iad bho
aoin gu anmhuinn – bho reite gu aireite
bho shocair gu an-shocair. 'Is truagh
nach robh mo bhathadh air bean a ghlug-
ain' – a proverb. / pathadh?

div.title: Druidh Achabheannaich
div.p:
Beagan cheum an ear air clach nan Druidh-
neach an Latheron, an Gallaobh tha carn agus
e thairis le fraoch. Am meadhoin a chuirn
tha cro beag mar altair. Tha e ri radh anns
an aite d' uair thainig druidh an teampuill
gu aois agus nach b' urrb' urrainn e na b' fhaide seirbh-
eis a thoir seachad le aois agus lapachd
gun do loisgeadh beo e air an altair so mar
iobairt reite. Am feadh a bha e losgadh
bha an druidh og a bha na aite dol deiseil
air an altair anns an deathaich agus ga h-ol
'Ex fumo dare lucem' a chum agus gun glac-
adh e Spiorad an t-seann druidh. 28/1 1874.

div.title: A Mhaighdean Mhara
div.p:
Thainig cro mara gu tir an Siabost an
LeothasLeodhas. Thainig a mhaighdean mhara
nan deigh. Chaidh muinntir a bhaile
chun a chladaich air tī a chruidh mhara
ghleidheadh air tir. Chrath iad maighstir
eadar an crodh mara agus a mhuir agus
cha b' urrb' urrainn an crodh tilleadh an taobh a thainig
iad Gun sin a dheanamh cha b' urrainn
na daoine an crodh a chumail. Thug
na daoine an crodh mara chon an taighe
a b' fhasg air braigh a chladaich. Lean
a mhaighdean-mharmhaighdean-mhara iad. Bha i ma thiom-
chioll seacuinseachduin air tir. Cha do chan i duird
re na h-uine ach tri facail. An deigh dha
na fir tighinn thar an iasgaich chunnaic i
na mnathan a glanadh an eisg agus thuirt i
ritheriutha -

lg.l: 'Nigh us glan gu math an t iasg
Is iomaiomadh biasd a tha s a mhuir.'

div.p:
Lean so na shean fhacal 's an aite
Bhiodh muinntirmnathan {an aitea bhaile chuile latha
a crathadh maighstir air druim nam
ba mara ach mu'n leigeadh iad a mach
's a mhaduinn iad. Ach latha dhe na laithean
dheanmaid iad so a dheanamha gus siod sios
dh fhalbh an crodh nan deann agus a muigh
air a mhuir gabhar iad. Chunnaic a
mhaighdean mhara so agus ruith us leum
agus a muigh air a mhuir bha i rompa
ag eigheach 's a gairm a chruidh mar so –

lg.l: O! gun tig Sitheag / O! gun tigeadh Sitheag
O! gun tig Seothag
O! gun tig Crom-an-taoid / nan taod
O gun tig Caoilteag bhàn
O gun tig Duibheag
O gun tig Doitheag
O gun tig Blarach ghaoil / Bearag
S O gun tig agus Caisfhionn ghraidh.
O gun tig Donnach mhoire a bhainnebhlath {bhruich{bhrich

div.p:
Tha mo chrodhsa so a tighinn ors a mhaigh-
dean mhara. Ach geid thì (chì?)sin an crodh
na thì(chì?) am buachaill. Ach mu ruith agus
mu reis an crodh ruith agus leum am buachaill.
Rug e air an te bu deirionnaich diudiubh air
earball a dol s an doimhne agus rug e gu
math oireoirre ach is ann leathse chaidh. D'uair
a chunnaic a mhaighdean-mhara cho
duineil agus a chaidh am buachaill an dail na bo
ris a bho las i le lasan agus thubhairt i –

lg.l: Nach luath Luran!
Nach loma-luath Luran!
Mar bhitheadh cruaidhs an arain
Na m' bu lioitlite agus bainne bu bu bhiadh do Luran
Cha bhiodh bo no laogh
Air mo thaobhsa gun chumail.

div.p: Is ann a sin a thoisich na daoin air deanamh lioitelite.

div.title: Mhaighdean Mhara
div.p:
A tighinn a nall an cuan Mor-thireach
(Minch) a Lochfraoin / Lochbhraoin / chunnaic
sgiobadh bata a mhaighdean mhara ag
eiridh aig an stiuir. Thubhairt fear de na
daoin – 'Sian fala air a bheisd.' Chaidh
i fodha agus dh-eirich ristrithist aig an stiuir agus
thubhairt i ris an stiuradairstiuireadair –

lg.l: Do churgan dubh air do leth-cheann
Cia do leth-rann?
Long a thig s a theid an aithghearr
Sin mo leth-rann.

div.p:
Is maith a chuir sin riut a mhicean ars ise agus chaidh
i fodha agus cha tainig i m barr tuillidh.

Thainig stoirm mhor mhor an lalatha sin agus
chaidh moran dhaoine dhi – moran moran
a mhilleadh agus a bhathadh. Uair air bith
a chite mhaighdean mhara bu tric gum
bitheadh bathaidhean mor air an dean-
amh gu aith-ghearraithghearr an deigh sin.

div.title: A Bhean Nighe
div.p:
Nam faiceadh neach a bhean-nighidh mu'n
faiceadh ĭs ěis cha b urrainn di carrachadh gus
am beireadh e oirre. Rug fear da m bainm
Iain ban taillear air bean nighidh agus i nigh-
eadh leine aig Lochan Dubh na Beinne. Ghuidh-
eam le laimh chli ors easan agus e breith
oirre. Is cearragach cruaidh a rug thu orm
ars ise: leig as mi! Cha leig ars easan cha
mhor an urrad so do mhnaoi dhomh fhein
Leig as mi ars ise agus bheir mi dhuit buaidh
De bhuaidh a bheir thu dhomh a bhronag?
Ars easan. Buaidh air bith a dh-iarras tu
ars ise. Dh-iarr e buaidh codach. Is bochd
buaidh t iarradais ars ise ach gheobh thu
mar a dh-iarr thu. Carson nach d-iarr
thu buaidh dhaoine agus buaidh larach?
Thoir dhomh sin cuideachd ors easan
Cha tobhair cha tabhair cha ghabh e dean-
amh ars ise ach gheobh thu mar a dh-iarr thu.
Ach cha suidh am mac na t aite agus
cha ghleidhear creimh air do threubh.

Is ann mar sin a bha – bha cuid agus
cothram gu leoir aig an duine Iain ban
taillear ach cha d-fhag e mac na nighean na aite
chon ainm a chumail air chuimhne.

Ciod e ta thu a nigheadh a so ars eise
Bha ars ise {eudach{leine na muinntir a bhith-
eas air am bathadh am bliadhna. Tha sgioba
bat eitheir gu bhi air am bathadh am
bliadhna ann an Tolasta o Thuath agus tha
mise nigheadh an eudaich aca. Ach o na ghlac-
adh an so mi cha'n fhaicear tuillidh mi.
Thachair mar a thubhairt bhathadh
sgiob eitheir an Tolasta o Thuath a
bhliadhna sin a tighinn dachaidh a
In Ionar-Uig – Wick – agus cha d fhuaradh
colann riamh dha na bha innte.
Rug fear air Bean-nighidh turas agus
thubhairt i ris – Co as luaithe mhothaich –
thusa no mise? Mis ars eise. Is math dhutsa
sin ors ise Leig as mi n deigh ors ise
agus thig mi maireach agus bithidh naigh-
eachd agam duit. Cha tig ars easan
a dheoin Dhia no n air rair ar-rair.

div.title: An t-Each Uisge.
div.p:
Bha nan each-uisgt-each-uisge og a cur dracagh mor
air teaghlach coir ann an Cair Carasiatar
d uair bhiodh fear an taighe bho'n bhaile
Le comhairle seann duine ghlic a bha
's a bhaile dh iarr e air fear an taighe e
chur eudach a mhna air agus d uair
thigeadh an t-seach uisg og chun an dorus
agus a dh-fheoreaicheadh e Co tha stigh
easan a fhreagar a toir cuireach dha
tighinn air aghart Mi-fein 's mi fein

Fhuair an t each uisg og droch laimh-
seachadh an oidhcheoidhche sin agus dh-fhalbh e –
agus gun an ran a chraos. Co rinn ort
Co dhiol s a gheullaichd thu ors an
an t-each uisge sean. Mi fein s mi fein
ors an t each uisge og. Nam bu fear eile
gun deanadh s mise gun dioladh ors
an seann each uisg.

div.title: An t-Each Uisge
div.p:
Bha e na chleachdchleachdadh aig each-uisg bhiodh
a tighinn air tir tighinn air cheilidh a
chumail comhraidh is conaltraigh ri
bean airich ann an Crageo d uair bhiodh
i na h-onar. Turas dha na tursan
chuir an t-aireach air aodach a mhna
agus thug e lamh air sniomh na cuigeil.
Thainig an t-each uisg as sheas e san
dorus agus thug e suil is taigh agus cha
tigeadh e na b'fhaide. Thubhairt e mar
so –

lg.l: 'An cuigeal siud/ud/ a th' aigesan
Us feusag air a ghuibean aige.'

div.p:
Bha triuir nighean a fantuinn ann an
Airidh Mhuthair. Thainig tri eich uisge
thuca ann an riochd triuir fhleasgach ghrinn.
Dh-fhan iad air an airiairidh re na h-oicheoidhche
Am marbhan na h-oicheoidhche mharbh
mharbh dithis dhe na h-eich uisge dithis
dha na h igheanan. Thar an trithibh te
as Ruith fear dha na h-eich uisge as
a deigh agus mar a ruith dh eubh

lg.l: Cha b'e an airiairidh shubhach
Ach an airiairidh dhubhach dheurach
Dh-ith sibhse bhur cuid 's bhur cubhaich
S mise dh-fhag mo chubhach fein mi.

div.add:
Thar an nighean so as le beatha le luathas a cos
Theirear Muthar na(n) Nighean Muthar na(m) Maighdean
ris an airiairidh gun an
lalatha nan diugh

div.title: An t-Each Uisge
div.p:
Bha nighean a buachailleachd spreidhe
ri taobh luich. Thainig oganach sgiobalt
donn far an robh i agus chuir e failt agus
furan oirre. Leig e cheann air a cota
agus chaidil e. Sheall ise gu maith air
a cheann agus chunnaic i lathaich agus
moraghain (grinneal) an luich na
chiabh agus dh-aithnich i gur h-e an
t-each uisge bh-ann. Ghearr i an cearb
de 'cota bha fo cheann agus thar i as.

D'uair a dhuisg an t-each uisge rug e air
a chearb aodaich a bha fo cheanna gus
chrath e an cearb ag radh – Ma's
duine tha n so is eutrom e! Mas duine
tha n so is eutrom e! Thar e as air
deoghaidh na h-ighinne agus thainig
e faisg air greim a dheanamh oirre
mu n do thar i taigh a h-athar a thoir
a mach. Chaidh i a cochal a cridhe
le eagal agus bhasaich i gearr an deigh
sin. Chaidh a brathair a mach an
la'r na mhaireach agus claidhe{dhana dhorn
– laimh – agus chomhlaich e n t-each uisg
agus mharbh e e.

div.title: Airidh Neill
div.p:
Thainig an t-each uisge chun airiAiridh Neill
nannam Beann ann an riochd mna. Dh-
aithnich coin Neill gur h-e bh' annnach bu bh]oir-
ionnach agus nach be a bh' ann ach an t-each uisge d uair
a chual iad i ri dranndail. CeaghailCeangail do choin
ors ise. Cha cheaghailcheangail an drasta orsa Niall
Thilg e ceathramh dhe n fheoil de h-ionnsuiionnsuidh
Dh-ith i suas siud naa dh-aona lan beoilbheoil!
Tilg thugam tuillidh ars ise. Cha tilginn
arsa Niall. CeaghailCeangail na coin ars ise rithis
Cha cheaghailcheangail an trasd arsa Niall. Leig e
mach na coin (as a deigh) ach cha do rinn
iad dad dhi. Leig e sin an t-soigh (saigh)
Mharbh an t-soigh i. An deigh a bais
bha i na lair mhoir bhain air an traigh.
CheaghailCheangail Niall a mhac rithe fad na
h-oicheoidhche chun an t-eagal a chur as!

Thainig an t-each uisge turas eile chun
Neill, ann an riochd maighdinn oig agus
dh-iarr i cuid na h-oichoidhche air. Thubhairt
i gur i Mor a b ainm dhi. Fhreagair Niall

lg.l: A Mhorag sin s a Mhorag
Cha mhor is fearrfhearr de na mnaimnaoi
S cha mhor a thachair ri m thaobh
Ach is eigineiginn gabhail leats a Mhor
O n tharladh dhuinn a bhi gun mhnaoi.

div.title: Uilliam Dean Suidhe
div.p:
Bha cailleach ann agus cha d-iarr i
riamh air duine suidhe na taigh. Chuir
Uilliam geall gun iarradh i airsan suidhe

Dh-fhalbh Uilliam agus thog e air agus
chai e thaigh na caillich – 'Cailleach an
doichil' – Chaidh e staigh agus chuir e
failt air a chaillich agus chuir a chail-
leach failt air {agus {ach] cha b' is in an fhailte
chridheil chaoimhneil! CodCiod e t-ainm
a thuine thaine thaine dhachaidh? ors a
chailleach. 'Uilliam dean Suidhe' ors Uilliam.
'Uilliam dean Suidhe!' ars a chailleach

Is mi ni {ars Uilliam {a chagair agus deagh
bhean an taighe ga iarraidh orm
Cailleach -

lg.l: Uilliam dean Suidhe
Mo ruighe chan fheaidefheairrde
Gheobh thu leacan lom
Us talamh toll us dearganan

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: A bhean thoir dhomhsa biadh
S leig eadar Dia mi 's an-shocair

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: Biadh cha'n eil agam dhomh féin

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: An i so cuil do ghleiteanais?
Thoisich Uilliam air rannsachadh tighe
na caillich agus fhuair e ceann agus

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: Ciod i duais fir dhalhaidh a chum a chailleach?

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: Is liom fein a bhalaich / bhodaich

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: Is liom fein e chailleach!

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: Suil 'us bus 'us eanachain!

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: An da cheir an da leir ard-cheann
labhairt a chuir na ceithir smior

luirgne agus an leac lom leis
an leth-cheann

div.p: Uilliam}Cailleach

lg.l: Cait an robh thu'n raoir?

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: An taigh fear eadragain.

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: CodCiod a fhuair thu ann?

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l:
Eitean chailltinn air an spealgadh
le geintinn chnamh.

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: Cuin a dhuisg thu?

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: D'uair chaidh an rionnach air a chruinneach.

div.p: Cailleach –
Uilliam –

lg.l:
Seoraichean chreag, bearnaichean
leac agus breacadh nan uillt.

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: Sac trom air a chois chaoil

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: Cha n eil an uidhe fada

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l: Ge beag goirid tha direadh ann.

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l: Cha luaith a direadh na a teurnadh

div.p: Cailleach –

lg.l:
Is neonach co geur /gearr/ 's a
tha thu agus nach bu bhard a
b' athair dhuit!

div.p: Uilliam –

lg.l:
Cha b ard s cha b'iosal ach anns
a mheud mheadhaonaich!

div.p:
The Macaulays of Lews were called out to
fight for Montrose the royalists under Montrose
All the able bodied men were called away
and after they left it occurred to them to send
back one of their number to defend the women
at home in case of need. The decision to returnlot odlyoddly enough
fell upon one Angus Macaulay – a man
who had a thorough shrew for his wife.

Macaulay protested but his protest was unheeded and he was made to go
back. His wife met him at a place since
called 'Clach AonaisAonghais'. Giving him a con-
temptuous withering look she said – Dh-fhalbh
na fir agus dh-fhuirich na fideacha-diol
(dĭdeacha dìde?). Stung by the reproach and without
going into his house the man turned back and awayfound
after his companions and was killed at the
battle of Auldearn – Allt-euran.

John Moireson Bragar Lews said of a wife whose
tongue was ever on the jar –

lg.l: Toiseach tus {air{an an-rath
An taigh an bi an toirm
An coileach {bhitric na thamh
A S a chearc a ghnath a gaoirm
The first origin of strife – misfortune
In the house wherein is "rattle"
When the cock is often silent – mute
And the hen is aye crowing.

div.p:
Seeing his neighbours catching fish in a
cruive and having no servant at hand to help
him in securing a share to John Moireson
threw off his cota mor saying to it as he did so –

lg.l: Ma sheallas sinn ris an uailse
Bithidh sinn s an uair so falamh
Bho nach fearrde sinn an fhalamhachd
Bith tus an trasda air failbhean na caire.
If it be to pride we look
We shall at this time be empty
But since we are not bettered by poverty
Thou must at present bereast on the corner of the cruive.

div.p:
After oppressing the people under him and
by tyrannising over them the Siamarlan – cham-
berlain was ignominiously dismissed. Another
was appointed in his place and John Moireson
of Bragar expressed his opinion of the two thus –

lg.l: Chuireadh Dughall fo na phrac
Mur nach togadh e i bho chacha neach riamh
'S mas e Macaulaidh is fearrfhearr / ceart
Chi cacha sin le 'ghniamh.
Dugald is placed under the prac
As though he had never exacted it of others
But if Macaulay is better / best
Others will see that by his deeds.

div.p:
Prac cain Kain the rent paid in kind as meal
butter cheese poultry eggs and cattle In exacting
these tributes somemanyof the factors were exceedingly tyran-
nical and overbearing trampling over the poor
people with a heart of stone.

John Moiresoan was summoned to Stornoway
as a juryman when at a time when he was busy
shearing. He was in a dilemma what to do and said

lg.l: Mu theid mi ann
Theid mi as
Mu dh-fhuireas mi as
Theid mi ann.
If I go there
I shall decline
If I keep from it away from it
I shall go there.

div.p:
This is a play upon words meaning that if he went
to Stornoway he would be a sufferer in means
and that if he kept away from it he would be
a gainer by it.

A factor died from being choked at dinner – being
a voracious man. When they were filling in the grave
in the grave over him John Moiresan said

lg.l: Cuiribh air! cuiribh air!
Is easan chuireadh oirnne!
Mu dh-eireas e rithist
Cuiridh e an corr oirnn.
Heap on him! heap on him!
Tis he who w'dwould heap on us
If he should rise again
He will heap more on us!

div.p:
John Moireson invited this factor to dine with him
and he came, but before sitting down to dinner host
and guest quarrelled and the guest left the house
in high dudgeon. As he was leaving Moireson flung
the following at him –

lg.l: Dh-fhalbh thu ruin 's cha mhiste liom
'S dh-fhag thu mo lionn agam feinfhein
'S air a chridhe tha nam fheoil
Dheanainn ol ge d' fheidheadh tu éig.
Thou hast left nor sorry am I
And thou hast left my ale to myself
And by the heart that's in my flesh
I'd drink though thou wouldst die!
